articles.headline: This Charleston Harbor Battle Is Over Cruise Ships
articles.snippet: A genteel South Carolina city is debating the benefits and disruptions of building a newer cruise ship terminal.
articles.abstract: A genteel South Carolina city is debating the benefits and disruptions of building a newer cruise ship terminal.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — In this Southern coastal city that runs on history and hospitality, a raucous civic debate belies a genteel veneer.

articles.headline: It Takes a B.A. to Find a Job as a File Clerk
articles.snippet: These days, Busch, Slipakoff & Schuh, a law firm in Atlanta, hires only people with a bachelor’s degree — no exceptions. And it is far from alone.
articles.abstract: These days, Busch, Slipakoff & Schuh, a law firm in Atlanta, hires only people with a bachelor’s degree — no exceptions. And it is far from alone.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA —The college degree is becoming the new high school diploma: the new minimum requirement, albeit an expensive one, for getting even the lowest-level job.

articles.headline:
Justices Take Case on
Overall Limit to
Political Donations
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court will examine caps on aggregate contributions by individual donors, setting the stage for what could end up as the most important campaign finance case since the 2010 decision in Citizens United.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court will examine caps on aggregate contributions by individual donors, setting the stage for what could end up as the most important campaign finance case since the 2010 decision in Citizens United.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday agreed to hear a challenge to federal campaign contribution limits, setting the stage for what may turn out to be the most important federal campaign finance case since the court’s 2010 decision in Citizens United, which struck down limits on independent campaign spending by corporations and unions.

articles.headline: Supreme Court Appears to Defend Patent on Soybean
articles.snippet: The case, over a farmer who reproduced and saved seeds patented by Monsanto, questions whether natural replication can constitute patent infringement.
articles.abstract: The case, over a farmer who reproduced and saved seeds patented by Monsanto, questions whether natural replication can constitute patent infringement.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A freewheeling and almost entirely one-sided argument at the Supreme Court on Tuesday indicated that the justices would not allow Monsanto’s patents for genetically altered soybeans to be threatened by an Indiana farmer who used them without paying the company a fee.

articles.headline: New Dreamliner Headache: Parking Space
articles.snippet: Cramped for space and reluctant to shut down its 787 production lines, Boeing is said to be looking for storage after the United States grounded the jetliners.
articles.abstract: Cramped for space and reluctant to shut down its 787 production lines, Boeing is said to be looking for storage after the United States grounded the jetliners.
articles.lead_paragraph: With the Federal Aviation Administration’s grounding of the 787 Dreamliner fleet in its fifth week, Boeing now faces a problem of where to store the airplanes that continue to roll off the assembly line at its giant factory 30 miles north of Seattle.

articles.headline: Battle Lines Drawn for BP’s Day in Court
articles.snippet: A collection of cases on the Deepwater Horizon spill are headed for federal court, where they are expected to have a broad effect on environmental law.
articles.abstract: A collection of cases on the Deepwater Horizon spill are headed for federal court, where they are expected to have a broad effect on environmental law.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Unless the Justice Department and BP reach a last-minute settlement, the British oil company will return to court on Monday to face tens of billions of dollars in civil claims from the 2010 explosion on the Deepwater Horizon rig in the Gulf of Mexico that could cripple the company for years to come.

articles.headline: Nickelodeon Hopes Its App Wins Hearts
articles.snippet: Nickelodeon designed its first app as a noisy, colorful smorgasbord of animated clips, music videos and games. But there’s very little actual television.
articles.abstract: Nickelodeon designed its first app as a noisy, colorful smorgasbord of animated clips, music videos and games. But there’s very little actual television.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nickelodeon has spent the last two years asking 9- and 10-year-olds what they want to watch on the iPad. The result: Very little actual television.

articles.headline: A Digital Shift on Health Data Swells Profits in an Industry
articles.snippet: As doctors and hospitals struggle to make new records systems work, the winners are big companies that lobbied for the legislation that allowed their sales to soar.
articles.abstract: As doctors and hospitals struggle to make new records systems work, the winners are big companies that lobbied for the legislation that allowed their sales to soar.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was a tantalizing pitch: come get a piece of a $19 billion government “giveaway.”

articles.headline: Robin Roberts Returns to ‘Good Morning America’
articles.snippet: Nearly six months after signing off ABC’s “Good Morning America” to fight a life-threatening illness, Robin Roberts made her return to the top-rated morning show on Wednesday.
articles.abstract: Nearly six months after signing off ABC’s “Good Morning America” to fight a life-threatening illness, Robin Roberts made her return to the top-rated morning show on Wednesday.
articles.lead_paragraph: 6:00 p.m. | Updated “Now,” Robin Roberts said to the staff of her top-rated morning show, “Good Morning America,” right after it wrapped on Wednesday, “we can resume regular programming.”
